captions.text:
Queen Lion of the Animal Kingdom is giving
more democracy to her citizens by adding a
legislative branch to the government.

The citizens each get one vote and are divided
into ranges. Each range will elect one representative
to send to the newly created Jungle Council.

To best understand how this system works,
lets look at a small colony where there are
just two political parties: Buffalo & Jackalope.

This colony is divided into four ranges. In
the first election Jackalope candidates win

two of them and buffalo candidates win the
rest.

All is well for several election cycles until
the Animal Kingdom Census taker comes round

and shows that the population has both moved
and grown.

To better represent the larger population
a new seat is added to the Jungle council
so the ranges' boundaries must be re-drawn.

This is where the trouble begins. Re-drawing
electoral boundaries is a huge political problem.

To help them, the representatives of the Jungle
Council hire a weaselly consultant to figure
out where the new boundaries should go.

If Weasel draws rectangular boundaries everything
is OK because the jungle council will, as

close as possible, reflect how the citizens
vote.

However, Weasel doesn't do this. Instead he
tells the Buffalo Party that, for a price,

he can turn their slim majority into a landslide
victory in the election.

With a super-majority on the Jungle Council
the Buffalo wouldn't have to listen to those

pesky Jackalope filibusters anymore, so the
Buffalo gladly pay up.

How can Weasel deliver on his promise? It's
depressingly simple: by packing together as

many jackalope voters into one range as possible
and spreading the rest of them out, The Buffalo

Party can win an additional seat without any
voters switching allegiance.

What Weasel and the Buffalo have done is called
'gerrymandering'. The intensional changing
of electoral boundaries for their benefit.

Several election cycles later the under-represented
and disgruntled Jackalope party approaches

Weasel and asks if he can manipulate the ranges
to be in their favor instead of the Buffalos'.

Indeed he can. Using the same trick, Weasel
packs Buffalo voters into a few ranges and
spreads the rest among the Jackalope supporters.

After the election the Jackalopes, who represent
a minority of the voters are now, nonetheless,
the majority party on the Jungle Council.

This is the terrible power of Gerrymandering:
Weasel can take the exact same voters and
get either party to win the election.

Unsurprisingly, Weasel's business grows and
eventually every colony in the Animal Kingdom
pays him to gerrymander their ranges.

With so many clients, Weasel now uses his
computer test hundreds of thousands of range

combinations with elaborate statistical models
of voter behavior to get the results he needs.

Queen Lion has seen what Weasel is up to and
banishes him from her kingdom. But, the census

taker reminds her that ranges still need to
be re-drawn as the population changes. So
how is it going to be decided?

Queen Lion suggests the obvious solution:
a bi-partisan committee must agree on all
new range boundaries.

This seems like a good idea. After all, if
both parties have to agree on the ranges,
then they must end up being fair to everyone.

But, after a few election cycles using this
solution, Queen Lion notices that she always

sees the same faces on the Jungle Council.
Representatives almost never get defeated
in their elections.

It turns out that the interests of the representatives
and the interests of the citizens are not

the same. Citizens want elections where the
candidates have to earn their vote. These

are close elections where either candidate
has a chance of winning.

But, representatives don't want close elections,
they want safe elections. Elections where
they run in a range that is filled with supporters.

Because the representatives are in change
of the boundaries they make the safest ranges
possible.

So, bi-partisan committees are not enough.
To truly fix gerrymandering there are three
options:

The first is to set up a politically independent
commission of appointed experts or judges
to draw the boundaries.

Independent commissions are much better than
bi-partisan committees, but still not ideal

because they usually group similar areas together
so the elections are uncompetitive.

And there is always the possibility that the
independent commission is not as independent
as it appears.

The second option is to let math decide the
boundaries. There are a number of ways to

mathematically divide an area into equally
populous ranges.

The simplest example of this is called the
'shortest split-line method'. Find the shortest

line that splits the voters in twain and repeat
as necessary until all the ranges are made.

This is much better than an 'independent'
commission, but it does have the problem of

occasionally producing skewed election results
just through pure bad luck of where the boundaries
are drawn.

But by publishing the algorithm used, all
citizens can check the results and be confident
that there is no intensional bias in the system.

The last solution is an unexpected one: hire
back the weasel and embrace gerrymandering.

But this time, pay him make the winners most
closely match the voters as a whole.

While it seems unsavory, this is actually
the best way to avoid disproportionate representation

which is, by far, the the worst problem of
gerrymandering.

But, considering these three solutions leaves
Queen Lion grumpy.

The first two are improvements, but still
may result in uncompetitive elections or disproportionate

results while the third just feels wrong.
Gerrymandering to avoid the problems of gerrymandering
is... odd.

Remembering what she learned about voting
before, she realizes all this gerrymandering

is really just a symptom of a more fundamental
problem: the method by which each citizen
gets only one vote and elects only one representative.

There are ways to eliminate gerrymandering
and restore competitive elections to make

her citizens happy, but to do that Queen Lion
is going to have to make some big, fundamental
changes to her democracy.

comments.text:
For some reason, I've seen an uptick of posts about Gerrymandering.  We'll, 
here's my link...

Gerrymandering is a huge problem, that is possible to solve in several 
different more or less good ways.  But, it's extremely unlikely any 
politician would ever vote for any of those solutions to become either law 
or reality.  What we see in reality, is politicians fighting hard against 
any attempt to limit their gerrymandering powers; e.g. recent lawsuit filed 
by Republicans.  In the meantime, we live with a system that has appearance 
that our votes make much of a difference.  But only appearance.  Sad faces 
and all.﻿

comments.text:
you could easily have a proportional system for each state. then local 
interests would still be represented. 

at the end of the day, the reason I support proportional over "first past 
the post" is because it #1 would undermine the 2-party system/give more 
choice and #2 the voters would better determine their representatives. no 
one can promise an unbiased group to draw lines. I believe in the bias of 
the people. 

"If men were angels, no government would be necessary." Madison
comments.author: Dustin Taylor

comments.text:
By no means are these proposed systems are the only solutions, but I think 
they are superior to the proportional representation system. The problem 
with proportional representation is something that was addressed at the 
beginning of this video, that the people usually want local representation, 
someone who is actually from their area to represent them. Without district 
lines, people may have a generally proportional system in terms of 
political party, but the specific interests for certain locations won't be 
represented.

comments.text:
I cannot remember if you say this in your video Grey so sorry if I only 
repeat you. Gerrymandering is more commonly known as "redistricting" in the 
US even though they are not the same. Redistricting is, by definition good 
and necessary, it is the use of gerrymandering that makes it corrupt. 
Gerrymandering is used so often, the term redistricting and gerrymandering 
gets interchanged. The same goes with political parties. Political Parties 
by definition is a good thing, it is a group of people with similar ideas 
coming together and sharing/supporting eachothers ideas. The political 
parties we know of (In almost every country) are corrupted and focus on 
making people of the party conform to the party's ideas, instead of 
supporting the growth of new and better ideas or systems.
For Americans if you want a real life and current (in respect to my current 
time typing this) example watch this 
http://thedailyshow.cc.com/full-episodes/xpjjio/october-30--2014---spoon 
START AT minute 10 

PS C.G.P Grey your videos are awesome keep up the good work. I do have 1 
favor please put links of the sources you used or links to find out more 
information about the topic of the video.﻿

comments.author: Tim Hershey

comments.text:
America has a unique situation.  Although its geographic representation 
system and primaries makes America far far more democratic than European 
countries with their parliamentary systems.  It also results in total 
gridlock which people regularly complain about.   

In my opinion gridlock is good, it prevents extremist ideas from getting 
through. It prevents dangerous and harmful stuff like socialized healthcare 
from the left or gay marriage bans on the right from getting through. And 
both sides are supposed to compromise in a way that keeps government 
efficient and limited. ﻿
comments.author: STDrepository

comments.text:
+STDrepository LOL No other Country likes our system because majority rules 
doesn't govern.
comments.author: Kevalry

comments.text:
Two party? Aren't we really talking about divide and rule?

Not all of us on this side of the pond are so dim as to think being screwed 
by two sides of the same corporate coin is in any way superior.

The American two party system is why I have no representation. For many 
years, in 3 successive Congressional Districts, I have dutifully gone to 
the polls and cast my vote for my preferred candidate only to be told, 
"Thank you for playing the democracy game. Too bad you lost. Play again 
soon." Ending up with a "representative" I voted against and with whom I 
strongly disagree on most issues. 

Nor am I alone. In a typical US election, 60% is a respectable margin, but 
60% turnout is also fairly typical. Also, a large number of eligible voters 
don't even register because they are totally disgusted with the system. So, 
in most districts, less than 36% of those supposedly represented voted for 
"their" representative.

How superior is that?
comments.author: John Kesich

comments.text:
+wcskjb
First I would like to point out that while there are only 2 parties in the 
US. It could be argued that each candidate is like its own sub-party.   
That's why you often hear names like "Ted Cruz Conservative" or "Obama 
Democrats"  

1. What does the media have to do with the system? You are free to start 
your own media and cover whoever you want. same with debates and funding.

2. And I would argue the lack of party bosses in the American system means 
thats not even an issue in the first place.

3. What the US lacks in party numbers it makes up for in party diversity 
and freedom. The lack of party bosses means that in Kentucky where jobs 
depend on coal the Democrats are completely at odds with the global warming 
agenda. There are also Democrats like Elizabeth Warren who are radical 
European style socialists.

(And i might add that Bernie Sanders is an independent socialist who was 
elected which shows that its not that its impossible to get a 3rd party, 
its just that most Americans are  far more satisfied with 2 choices than 
 is often claimed)

Independent Bernie Sanders by the way. Would be perfectly at home in the 
Democrat party and theres really no reason for him to even be an 
independent. The voters who elected him are served equally well with him as 
a Democrat.
comments.author: STDrepository

comments.text:
+wcskjb You are right about the advantages of parliamentary systems and you 
could have added that deadlock is less likely than with a Jeffersonian 
system but proportional representation (PR) by Single Transferable Vote 
(STV) is even better than proportional representation by party lists. 
 Among its other advantages, STV maximizes voter choice, increases voter 
power and decreases party power.

STDrepository said that gridlock controlled extremists but only when there 
happens to be gridlock and, as the USA has experienced, it can cause 
considerable inconvenience or worse.  Parliamentary democracy with PR 
provides much more effective control of extremism as it reduces the 
possibility that any one party has total control.
comments.author: Anthony Tuffin

comments.text:
+STDrepository Your comparison of what I'll call the Euro-centric 
parliamentary system and the Jeffersonian democracy system overlooks some 
very important real-world factors:
1. New party formation and expansion is much easier under the parliamentary 
system as practiced in most such countries. Both systems inhibit new 
parties to an extent, but it's far worse in the U.S. system, which 
handicaps them by limiting ballot, funding and debate participation, and 
where the "free" news media ignores them more than media do in 
parliamentary systems.
2. In the parliamentary system, the candidate-picking bosses always have to 
be wary of losing their share of the vote to spin-off parties that are 
focused on narrower minorities - such as, in your example, anti-abortion 
socialists - so they need to field slates that at least acknowledge the 
extremes within their ranks. Such "niche" voter groups tend to be crowded 
out in a two-party dominated system, but can more easily, if they field 
talented candidates, win seats in parliaments. 
3. Proportional voting by party improves representation by subdividing the 
lawmaking body into interest groups that represent smaller shares of the 
electorate. Very many Americans feel that their views are not represented 
by either the Republican or Democratic platforms, but they have very few 
options to challenge them. A third-party movement still faces challenges 
vs. established parties in a parliamentary system, but their odds of 
winning a seat or two are far greater there.
comments.author: wcskjb

but using your own logic negative things would happen just  as easy in that 
setting..like instead using a safe waste disposal of a region it will get 
thrown in the river of the next because that 1 representative somehow 
vetoed and won against the rational solution ).



And a parliamentary representation or at least more diversity in governing 
bodies is actually more democratic in the cases where it is in place, 
because it´s concentrating less power in single entities generally, which 
is distancing it further from what dictatorships are and trying more to 
represent different  people/voters in the populace and have less focused 
power in such single persons or parties. (which the US doesn´t have to the 
degree of some other countries, so not sure how one could rationally 
determine it to be the most democratic, except for some heavy confirmation

(I´m not sure about the Dutch though which you referred above, but you seem

Also your reasoning fails about party and representative distinctions 
 because it´s not about which person or thing you choose, it´s about what 
program/content and direction of government you agree with most being 
represented, no matter who/what will represent...except it´s about 
 personal biases and cults which is the decision maker... but less personal

comments.author: Caarnji

comments.text:
+Daan Dekker  Well better is an opinion so if you like your system than 
that is great.  But as far as how democratic the systems are, there is no 
comparison. The US system gives people far more control in electing 
representatives to government and provides far more accountability for 
those representatives.

I can explain more in detail..
First off there is the lack of a primary in the European parliament system. 
 This means that instead of the people choosing the candidates, the 
candidates are chosen by a few party bosses.  If you for example want to 
vote for the Socialist party, but the Socialist party boss has chosen 
candidates who all  support abortion but you are a Socialist who supports 
the right of a baby to life.  
You really have no option at all..  

However in the primary system, you could first vote to choose a socialist 
party candidate who is pro-life, and then if he wins the nomination for 
your area, you can then vote for him in the general election.   Even if 
there are no  pro-life socialist party candidates, you yourself can run in 
the primary as a pro-life socialist. Even if the party boss doesn't want 
you to. 

There is also the geographic representation system, which ties a seat to a 
specific area usually consisting of just a handful of towns or part of a 
large city. 

Lets look at an example,  say the Dutch government chose your tiny town as 
the site for a nuclear waste disposal pit.  Obviously you would not be 
happy about this, but what can you do?  The rest of Holland doesn't care, 
and your town has a small population and could never influence the 
parliament. You would have to try to start some kind of national awareness 
campaign and hope people listen.

But in the geographic representation system, you have your own 
representative who is in the parliament who's only job is to serve your 
area. He could filibuster other legislation and cause trouble until the 
rest of the legislators agree to move the nuclear waste. Or he could refuse 
to vote for legislation unless it includes an amendment to move the waste 
site.  Either way, the end result is the minorities are protected from 
being abused by the majority. This protection does not occur in a popular 
vote only system.
comments.author: STDrepository

comments.text:
Sorry but i disagree completely with you. Our parliamentary system is far 
better (in the Netherlands at least). The way our government works is by 
letting everybody vote on 1 political party. Those parties get an 
representative number of seats (don't know the proper word) in our 
government. This eliminates all problems you can have with elections 
because it is just a fair way of electing. No district boundary nonsense. 
The only slight problem is that no party will every be likely to have a 
majority of seats. This means that parties have to cooperate in getting 
legislature passed.

No surprise you also think gridlock somehow represents the will of the
